title: Se pencher
content:
Bend over
Exemple: James dropped his pen, so he bent over to pick it up.

title: Souffler
content:
Blow out
Exemple: She blew out all the candles.

title: Entrer en effraction
content:
Break in
Exemple: Thieves broke in and raided the safe.

title: Inspirer
content:
Breathe in
Exemple: Don’t breathe in: there may be toxic fumes in the air.

title: Expirer
content:
Breathe out
Exemple: The doctor asked the patient to breathe out slowly.

title: Rapporter/ramener
content:
Bring back
Exemple: The teacher asked him to bring back the homework.

title: Rencontrer par hasard/rentrer dans
content:
Bump into
Exemple: I bumped into him while walking to school.

title: Eclater/fondre (en larmes)
content:
Burst into
Exemple: My friend burst into tears after finding out his last history grade.

title: Rappeler
content:
Call back
Exemple: I’ll call back when I can.

title: Annuler
content:
Call off
Exemple: The town’s annual picnic was called off due to rain.

title: Rendre visite à
content:
Call on
Exemple: John called on his friends for support.

title: Passer
content:
Call round
Exemple: Peter said that he would call round sometime this afternoon.

title: Se soucier de
content:
Care about
Exemple: I care about the issue of global warming.

title: S’occuper de / aimer
content:
Care for
Exemple: Juliana still cares for Simon after all these years.

title: Continuer
content:
Carry on
Exemple: She carried on as if nothing had happened.

title: Courrir après
content:
Chase after
Exemple: The police chased after the burglar and caught him in my neighbour’s garden.

title: Chasser
content:
Chase away
Exemple: Chase away that dog before it eats your food.

title:
Se présenter à
l’enregistrement / la réception
content:
Check in
Exemple: What time may we check in to our hotel room?

title: Régler sa note / regarder
content:
Check out
Exemple: The inspector checked out the suspect’s alibi by questioning his friends.

title: Vérifier / Examiner
content:
Check over
Exemple: I always check over the engine carefully before a long car journey.

title: Dégager / Filer
content:
Clear off (familier)
Exemple: I’m busy now - clear off!

title: Vider
content:
Clear out
Exemple: Anita cleared out all the closets in preparation for the move.

title: Passer par-dessus
content:
Climb over
Exemple: Even if you manage to climb over the prison fence, the dogs will be waiting on the other side.

title: Se couvrir / s’assombrir
content:
Cloud over
Exemple: The day started fine and sunny, but by midday it began to cloud over, and by late afternoon it was raining hard.

title: Venir / Reprendre connaissance / se raviser (changer d’avis)
content:
Come around
Exemple: The patient came around soon after his operation.

title: Revenir
content:
Come back
Exemple: I came back from the office at about 6.30pm.

title: Entrer
content:
Come in
Exemple: Please come in; the door is open.

title: Se détacher
content:
Come off
Exemple: Once they are firmly stuck on, the labels won’t come off.

title: Sortir / partir
content:
Come out
Exemple: Did you ask your mom if you can come out and play?

title: Venir
content:
Come over
Exemple: If you come over this evening we’ll watch a movie together.

title: Reprendre connaissance
content:
Come to
Exemple: When he came to, he was in hospital.

title: Rayer
content:
Cross off
Exemple: Make a list of things to do and cross off each item once you have completed it.

title: Barrer
content:
Cross out
Exemple: With a pencil you can erase; with a pen you have to cross out your mistakes. Cross out the wrong answers.

title: Traverser
content:
Cross over
Exemple: I want to cross over the river.

title: Pousser un cri
content:
Cry out
Exemple: Laura cried out in pain when she twisted her ankle.

title: Couper
content:
Cut off
Exemple: His leg was so badly damaged, the doctors had to cut it off.

title: Découper
content:
Cut out
Exemple: When I was little, I loved cutting out pictures from magazines.

title: Suivre
content: To keen up with

title: Faire ses débuts
content: To start out

title: Préparer
content: Make up

title: A lot
content:
A LOT (adverb)
plenty, numerous, countless, a great deal, a large amount

title: Really
content:
REALLY (adverb)
genuinely, truly, honestly, undoubtedly, certainly, remarkably, incredibly, downright, unquestionably, extremely

title: Very
content:
VERY (adverb)
extremely, exceedingly, exceptionally, immensely, tremendously, abundantly, particularly, remarkably, overly

title: Afraid
content:
AFRAID (adjective)
scared, frightened, terrified, petrified, startled, alarmed, shocked, horrified, panicked, apprehensive

title: Angry
content:
ANGRY (adjective)
cross (en colère), annoyed (contrarié), irritated, fuming / irate (furieux), exasperated

title: Bad
content:
BAD (adjective)
unacceptable, unsuitable (inapproprié), undesirable, absurd, appalling (épouvantable ), awkward (étrange, maladroit, bizarre),evil (malfaisant), false, foolish, groundless (sans fondement), harmful (nuisible, nocif), unfortunate (fâcheux), serious, useless, hopeless, awful, dreadful, inconvenient (inopportune, gênant), critical, wretched (misérable, pitoyable), loathsome (répugnant, détestable)

title: Beautiful
content:
BEAUTIFUL (adjective)
stunning / dazzling (éblouissant), magnificent, lovely, charming, gorgeous, radiant (resplendissant), exquisite, ravishing (ravissant), bewitching (enchanteur, charmeur)

title: Big
content:
BIG (adjective)
huge, enormous, large, outstanding (remarquable, marquant), tremendous (énorme, formidable), significant, fantastic, gigantic,massive

title: Difficult
content:
DIFFICULT (adjective)
challenging (ardu, exigeant), arduous, strenuous (éprouvant, fatigant), laborious, grueling (exténuant), demanding (exigeant), severe (extreme, violent, rude), burdensome (pesant, pénible).

title: Easy
content:
EASY (adjective)
effortless, simple, smooth (sans pb), straightforward (simple, franc), uncomplicated, painless (sans effort), accessible, basic, elementary

title: Funny
content:
FUNNY (adjective)
comical, ludicrous (grotesque), amusing, droll, entertaining (divertissant) , hilarious, whimsical (fantaisiste), witty (plein d’esprit), humorous

title: Good
content:
GOOD (adjective)
fine, positive, appropriate, convenient, satisfactory, suitable (qui convient, approprié), attractive, convincing (convainquant), powerful (puissant), competent, admirable, reliable (fiable), well-grounded (argument fondé, qui s’y connaît), efficient (efficace), relevant (pertinent), acceptable

title: Happy
content:
HAPPY (adjective)
cheerful, delighted, pleased, content (satisfait), amused, thrilled (très heureux, surexcité), elated / ecstatic (fou de joie), overjoyed

title: Important
content:
IMPORTANT (adjective)
major, significant (significative), decisive, crucial, essential, paramount (primordial, capital), capital, fundamental, vital, notable, meaningful

title: Interesting
content:
INTERESTING (adjective)
captivating, curious, exciting, fascinating, stimulating, thought-provoking, appealing, gripping, engaging, enticing (attirant, séduisant), intriguing

title: Necessary
content:
NECESSARY (adjective)
basic, compulsory (obligatoire), essential, vital, urgent, a matter of life and death, indispensable, imperative, unavoidable (inévitable)

title: New
content:
NEW (adjective)
unused, fresh, pristine (pur, immaculé), modern, contemporary, latest (le plus recent), emerging, state-of-the-art (dernier cri)

title: Nice
content:
NICE (adjective)
lovely, satisfying, amiable / friendly / charming (aimable), delightful / pleasant / congenial / agreeable (agréable)

title: Sad
content:
SAD (adjective)
miserable (malheureux), gloomy (maussade), devastated, distraught (bouleversé, désemparé), distressed (bouleversé, ébranlé), dispirited (démoralisé), sorrowful, downcast, desolate, forlorn (triste, mélancolique)

title: Small
content:
SMALL (adjective)
insignificant, limited, minor, tiny (minuscule), weak (faible)

title: Idea
content:
IDEA (noun)
an aim, an ambition, an aspiration, a goal, a notion, an opinion, a belief, a conviction, a feeling, a (point of) view, an impression, an objective, a guess, an outlook (un point de vue, une perspective), a concept

title: Problem
content:
PROBLEM (noun)
a dilemma, an issue, a puzzle, a difficulty, a critical/awkward/hopeless situation

title: To eat
content:
TO EAT (verb)
to chomp (mâcher bruyamment), to gulp (engloutir), to crunch, to devour

title: To get
content:
TO GET (verb)
to acquire, to obtain, to receive, to gain, to earn (gagner de l’argent en travaillant), to gather (rassembler), to collect, to purchase, to attain, to score

title: To give
content:
TO GIVE (verb)
to grant (accorder), to donate, to hand out (distribuer), to present, to provide (fournir), to deliver, to hand over (remettre), to offer, to award, to bestow (accorder), to bequeath (léguer, transmettre)

title: To go
content:
TO GO (verb)
to move, to proceed (advancer), to advance, to progress, to travel, to walk, to journey, to depart, to flee

title: To have
content:
TO HAVE (verb)
to keep, to own, to possess, to retain (garder, conserver), to enjoy, to manage, to experience

title: To look
content:
TO LOOK (verb)
to peek / to glimpse / to peer / to glance (jeter un coup d’oeil), to stare / to gaze (regarder fixement), to observe, to examine, to eye, to inspect, to watch

title: To make
content:
TO make (verb)
to cause, to create, to produce, to concoct, to assemble, to fabricate, to engineer

title: To say
content:
TO SAY (verb)
to admit, to add, to announce, to answer, to ask sb, to declare, to demand (exiger), to deny (nier), to enquire (se renseigner, s’informer), to explain, to mention, to offer (proposer), to promise, to remind sb (rappeler à qqn), to repeat, to reply (répondre), to retort (rétorquer), to cry, to moan (rouspéter, maugréer), to scream, to shout, to yell (hurler), to grumble (grommeler), to mumble (marmonner), to murmur, to mutter (grommeler), to whisper (chuchoter), boast (se vanter), to complain, to confess, to deplore, to insist, to maintain (soutenir), to object, to threaten (menacer), to whine (se plaindre)

title: To see
content:
TO SEE (verb)
to perceive, to notice, to catch a glimpse of entrevoir), to catch sight of (entrevoir), to detect, to discern, to lay eyes on poser les yeux sur), to regard

title: To think
content:
TO THINK (verb)
to believe, to assume, to feel, to imagine, to picture, to suppose, to admit, to consider, to ponder (réfléchir), to conceive, to contemplate (envisager)

title: To understand
content:
TO UNDERSTAND (verb)
to figure out, to realize, to interpret, to see

title: Décoller (sens propre et figuré)
content:
Take off
Exemples: The new product really took off and everybody wanted it. / The plane took off after a short delay.

title: Tenir de quelqu’un ou ressembler à
content:
Take after
Exemple: Many people say that Maria takes after her grandmother.

title: Se mettre à / Accepter
content:
Take up
Exemples: He took up woodworking after inheriting his grandfather’s tools. / You’ll do the work for just £20? Great - I’ll take you up on that offer!

title: Prendre la relève / Prendre le contrôle de
content:
Take over
Exemple: Take over the meeting for me, I’ll be back in a moment.

title: Retirer ce que (j’ai) dit
content:
Take back
Exemples: I wish I could take back what I said in anger. / You can never really take back an insult once you’ve made it.

title: Une bonne affaire
content: A bargain

title: Un centre commercial
content: A mall (US)

title: Un vendeur
content: An assistant

title: Avancer / ici jouer avec le jeu
content: To go along

title: Difficile
content: Tricky

title: Comprendre (understand)
content: To get one’s head round it

title: Classer / ici résoudre, régler
content: To sort

title: Renforcer
content: To strengthen

title: Prendre la peine de
content: To bother

title: La vue (landscape)
content: Scenery

title: Douloureux (painful)
content: To be sore

title: Abandonner (to give up)
content: To quit

title: Avoir mal (to hurt)
content: To ache

title: Sage
content: Wise

title: Améliorer (improve)
content: To enhance

title: Continuer quelque chose (to continue)
content: To keep V+ing

title: Assurer l’entretien de
content: To maintain the garden

title: Un macareux
content: A puffin

title: Un nid
content: A nest

title: Courtaud
content: A squat body

title: Courtaud
content: A squat body

title: Un bec
content: A beak

title: Se propulser
content: To propel oneself

title: Des freins
content: Brakes

title: Changer / Modifier (to change)
content: To alter

title: Plonger
content: To dive

title: Retenir sa respiration
content: To hold one’s breath

title: Une falaise
content: A cliff

title: Une corniche, un rebord
content: A ledge

title: Pondre (un oeuf)
content: To lay an egg

title: Éclore
content: To hatch

title: Une oie
content: A goose

title: Jeter un coup d’oeil / ici pépier, gazouiller
content: To peep

title: Faire signe / ici attirer, appeler (fig)
content: To beckon somebody

title: Quitter (to leave)
content: To head out to

title: Une menace
content: A threat

title: Qui guette
content: Lurking

title: Errer
content: To roam

title: Une experience gratifiante
content: A rewarding experience

title: Planer
content: To glide

title: Sortie / Libération
content: A release

title: Être fan de
content: To be into

title: Le plus récent
content: The latest (model)

title: D’une certaine façon
content: Somehow

title: Assuré, confiant
content: Confident

title: Une aptitude
content: An ability

title: Il y a de la place pour
content: There is room for

title: Objectif (goal)
content: Purpose

title: Bizarre (strange)
content: Weird

title: Un manque de (a lack of)
content: A shortage of

title: Gêné, mal à l’aise
content: Self-conscious

title: Mettre quelqu’un à l’aise
content: To put someone at ease ≠ ill at ease

title: Diffuser
content: To broadcast

title: Une compétence
content: A skill

title: Se plaindre
content: To complain
